Jamie Foxx is a multi-talented American actor, comedian, singer, songwriter, and record producer. Born Eric Marlon Bishop on December 13, 1967, in Terrell, Texas, he grew up in a musical family and began playing piano at the age of 5. Foxx attended United States International University, where he studied music and comedy.

After moving to Los Angeles, Foxx began his career in the entertainment industry as a stand-up comedian and actor. He created and starred in the TV series "The Jamie Foxx Show" (1996-2001), which earned him several NAACP Image Award nominations. Foxx's early success led to roles in films like "Toys" (1992), "The Players Club" (1998), and "Any Given Wednesday" (1999).

In the 2000s, Foxx's career reached new heights with his critically acclaimed performances in films like "Ray" (2004), for which he won the Academy Award for Best Actor, "Collateral" (2004), and "Django Unchained" (2012). He has collaborated with notable artists like Kanye West, Justin Timberlake, and Pharrell Williams.

Throughout his career, Foxx has received numerous awards and nominations, including multiple Grammy, Golden Globe, and BET Awards. He has been recognized for his philanthropic work, particularly in the areas of education and children's health.

In 2019, Foxx won his second Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role as a musician in "Just Mercy." He continues to be a respected and versatile entertainer, exploring various genres and projects, including television, film, and music.

That's Jamie Foxx in a nutshell!
